description: US, c. 1908; compare earlier lyophilize (1894). lyo- (“solvent, dispersion”) +‎ -philic (“having affinity for”), from Ancient Greek λύω (lúō, “to loosen, to dissolve”) + φίλος (phílos, “beloved”) + Latin -icus.

adjectives.description: lyophilic (comparative more lyophilic, superlative most lyophilic)

entries.meaning: (chemistry, of a colloid) Having an affinity for the dispersion medium and thus not easily precipitated.
examples: In second sub-group, the “emulsion-colloids” or “lyophilic colloids,” the properties of the solvent are considerably influenced. The internal friction, surface tension, and other properties of the liquid show great changes even when only a small proportion of matter is in colloidal solution.
